messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] EXCELLENT!!! and startin' off with a question...
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Matt et all,  Ithink that is exactly what I was saying. Thinner lighter tsuba were used for one handed sword action as the use of the sword was generally
messages.messageBody:
Hi Matt et all, Ithink that is exactly what I was saying. Thinner lighter tsuba were used for one handed sword action as the use of the sword was generally mounted ( from the horse ), later on in the The Muromachi, the action moved two the ground and became two handed ( both hands were free ) the sword didn't need to be as light and the tsuba became heavier to cope with the balance required for two handed use.

This is at least how I recall it, I stand corrected and look for guidence if I am off the mark, especially with the periods I quoted, I'm trying this from memory.

Rich T
----- Original Message -----
From: Matthew E. Hoyle
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, April 23, 2003 12:24 PM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] EXCELLENT!!! and startin' off with a question...


What about the use of the tsuba for balancing the sword ? Doesn't that
play an important role as well ?

I read in a piece by R. B. Caldwell that since the kamakura tachis were
so well balanced by themselves (he described them as prima donnas haha)

they really only needed a light lacquered leather guard.

So it stands to reason that the Nambokucho massive swords that had
little fumbari were no where near as well balanced and must have needed
massive tsuba to match ??

Or small ones that were 2.5 inches wide and 1 inch thick of course
hahaha

- Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Richard Turner [mailto:ikkanshi@...]
Verzonden: donderdag 24 april 2003 6:16
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] EXCELLENT!!! and startin' off with a
question...


This is an interesting topic, I have just been lent The Picture Book of
Old Tsuba by Robert Burawoy to read and enjoy and there are several of
these
very tsuba in this book. I remember reading that the tsuba size changed
when fighting went from one handed mounted to two handed ground
fighting. There are several nice smaller cast pieces in this book that
are from the nambokucho period. There is also a very nice red lacquer
that was a used by certain Priests I believe that loos spectacular. I
will research this more later in the day and respond with proper
information.

cheers

Rich Turner

very tsuba in this book. I remember reading that the tsuba size changed when fighting went from one handed mounted to two handed ground fighting. There are several nice smaller cast pieces in this book that are from the nambokucho period. There is also a very nice red lacquer that was a used by certain Priests I believe that loos spectacular. I will research this more later in the day and respond with proper information.

cheers

Rich Turner

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] EXCELLENT!!! and startin' off with a question...
messages.msgSnippet: If anyone is interested, I can send you a copy of the Excel spreadsheet that Richard mentioned.  While hardly a scientific sample, what I did was to go through
messages.messageBody:
If anyone is interested, I can send you a copy of the Excel spreadsheet that
Richard mentioned. While hardly a scientific sample, what I did was to go
through the Tokyo National Museum Uchigatana Koshirae book and record the
tsuba diameter, saya length and tsuka length for each illustrated katana or
wakizashi koshirae. It's somewhat interesting to play with.

It turns out that correlation between saya length (a proxy for blade length)
and tsuba diameter is fairly weak. The correlation between tsuka length and
tsuba size is actually better. The correlation between saya length and
tsuka length is very good.

The average katana tsuba is 8.03 cm in diameter, but the range is 5.85-10.80
cm.
The average wakizashi tsuba is 6.59 cm in diameter, with a range of 4.90 to
8.60 cm.

So, making definite statements about katana-size or wakizashi-sized tsuba on
size alone is pretty difficult. There are no dates given for most of the
koshirae in the book, so that is not included in the spreadsheet. There's
more work to do here.

Jim


> Jim G. actually created a database from the uchigatana book, but I'm not
> sure he put the dates in so I can't xref to that.
>
> rkg
>

>

Old Tsuba by Robert Burawoy to read and enjoy and there are several of these
> >very tsuba in this book. I remember reading that the tsuba size changed
when fighting went from one handed mounted to two handed ground fighting.
There are several nice smaller cast pieces in this book that are from the
nambokucho period. There is also a very nice red lacquer that was a used by
certain Priests I believe that loos spectacular. I will research this more
later in the day and respond with proper information.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] EXCELLENT!!! and startin' off with a question...
messages.msgSnippet: Richard, The Nambokucho O-dachi koshirae that I have seen have moderate-sized tsuba. I don t have measurements handy, but the ones I m thinking of are nerikawa
messages.messageBody:
Richard,
The Nambokucho O-dachi koshirae that I have seen have moderate-sized tsuba.
I don't have measurements handy, but the ones I'm thinking of are nerikawa
tsuba that I would estimate to be in the 8 cm diameter range.
Proportionally, they look rather small on these very long koshirae.

This would seem to favor the idea that the tsuba functioned as a hand stop
or a hand guard (or probably both) and that there was no need to scale the
tsuba up beyond hand-sized.

On the other hand, some of the very large Ko-Tosho and Ko-Katchushi tsuba
are attributed to the Nambokucho jidai. This may or may not be correct. I
don't recall seeing a pre-Muromachi period koshirae mounted with one of
these.

The question of tsuba size changing with time and function is a complicated
one that I don't think I have a pat answer for. It's something I'd like to
continue to trade ideas on though.

Jim


> Jim,
>
> good idea - my delete finger was getting a little sore at certain
> members' political diatribes, etc.,.
>
> There was an interesting thread started that I'd guess we all can talk
> about here. And that would
> be tsuba size.
>
> I believe Jim has seen real nambokucho koshirae (or what's left of 'em)
> - what size were the tsuba on these
> monsters anyway?
>
> Also, was the tsuba size a "fashion" thing in general, or did it really
> tend to get bigger during eras of war?
>
> Anyway, thanks for taking the initiative to try and get some serious
> conversation back into a sword list...
>
> rkg
> (Richard George)
>
>

messages.msgSnippet: Jim, good idea - my delete finger was getting a little sore at certain members political diatribes, etc.,. There was an interesting thread started that I d
messages.messageBody:
Jim,

good idea - my delete finger was getting a little sore at certain
members' political diatribes, etc.,.

There was an interesting thread started that I'd guess we all can talk
about here. And that would
be tsuba size.

I believe Jim has seen real nambokucho koshirae (or what's left of 'em)
- what size were the tsuba on these
monsters anyway?

Also, was the tsuba size a "fashion" thing in general, or did it really
tend to get bigger during eras of war?

Anyway, thanks for taking the initiative to try and get some serious
conversation back into a sword list...

rkg
(Richard George)
